thread.title: Dutch teams will have to qualify for Champions League from now on after they lose their automatic spot
thread.title_full: Dutch teams will have to qualify for Champions League from now on after they lose their automatic spot

author: jhutchinson
title: Dutch teams will have to qualify for Champions League from now on after they lose their automatic spot
text:
EFL DUTCH DESPAIR Dutch teams will have to qualify for Champions League from now on after they lose their automatic spot 
AZ Alkmaar were hammered 4-1 at home to Lyon last night, while Ajax laboured to a 0-0 draw away to Legia Warsaw by JOHN HUTCHINSON Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments THE winner of the Dutch top flight will have to qualify for the main draw of the Champions League next season. 
As a result of both Ajax and AZ Alkmaar failing to win in last night’s Europa League games, the Eredivisie has lost its automatic qualification place for Europe’s elite club competition. AP:Associated Press 4 AZ Alkmaar were hammered 4-1 by Lyon to leave their Europa League hopes in tatters 
The Dutch league is now ranked 13th overall, and as a result of slipping outside the top 10, the top two teams will enter at the qualifying stage. 
Keep up to date with ALL the FOOTBALL news, gossip, transfers and goals on our club page plus fixtures, results and live match commentary 
The third placed team will enter the Europa League at the third round stage. Getty Images Ajax will have it all to do at home when they take in a 0-0 draw from their first leg away at Legia Warsaw Related Stories FOLLOWERS OF PASSION Lincoln's Cowley brothers are obsessed with football... and their eye for detail has turned Non-League Imps into feared giant-slayers ROO BETTER BELIEVE IT Manchester United could still flog skipper Wayne Rooney this month despite transfer window closing SCARED OF SCORING Claudio Ranieri says Leicester are full of fear in front of goal... but he won't be too scared to drop them FA People's Cup The FA is looking for passionate football bloggers and YouTubers to take part in the FA People's Cup Reffin' hell Premier League faces referee crisis with Michael Oliver targeted by MLS... just 48 hours after Mark Clattenburg quit NEW STRIKER Sleepy Lee...but will the defender's error cost his side? ROAR EMOTION Sutton striker Roarie Deacon has a photo of him signing for Arsenal pride of place in his home... now he is back in the frame for Arsene Wenger BALLS-UP FA hit Leyton Orient's Liam Kelly with six-match ban for pushing over Plymouth ballboy Beer we go All hands to the pump as Sutton United order 6,000 extra pint glasses for visit of Arsenal APPLE'S BEARING FRUIT Michael Appleton passes Oxford exam as he eyes Boro KO after beating Newcastle Jose's Cup of tea Jose Mourinho claims foreign bosses don't respect the FA Cup... but he will never field a weakened side 24/ 7 heaven 4 
Even if both Ajax and Alkmaar reach the Europa League final, they would still not break into the top ten as a result of their co-efficient points from European victories. 
Lyon will take a commanding lead into their second leg against AZ Alkmaar after teenager Lucas Tousart scored his first senior goal and Jordan Ferri rounded off the scoring in stoppage time either side of Alexandre Lacazette’s double. 
Alireza Jahanbakhsh had reduced the deficit for AZ with a 68th-minute penalty, but the 4-1 scoreline will take some turning round. 
Ajax were held to a 0-0 draw at Legia Warsaw. The Dutch outfit had 21-year-old defender Kenny Tete sent off late in the game for two bookable offences. Usain Bolt claims he would be as good as Wayne Rooney at football Getty Images AZ Alkmaar were left stunned as they were battered 4-1 at home to French outfit Lyon
